titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid to the Rosemary Keefe Curb papers SSC.MS.00680
titlestmt.author: Madison White

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-10-09 15:52:20 -0400.

change.item: This record was migrated from InMagic DB Textworks to ArchivesSpace.

did.abstract: The collection includes the professional papers of Rosemary Keefe, a noted Women's Studies scholar, including her Feminist Theater Archives, assembled as part of her research, and her correspondence, scripts, fliers, and publications, by Keefe and others.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is stored offsite; researchers must give 48 hours advance notice. Collection is unprocessed and so may be difficult to use.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: This collection is comprised of the following accessions, some of which may not have accession records. Accession numbers: 11S-27, 11S-57, 13S-41, 15S-44. Accessions were received on the following dates: 2011-05-31, 2011-11-11, 2013-07-24, 2015-06-11.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Smith College received the collection as a gift from Rosemary Keefe in 2011 and 2013, as well as from Doris Burkemper in 2015.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Born in Chicago, Rosemary Keefe Curb received her BA in Biology from Rosary College, part of Dominican University in Illinois in 1962. As Sister Mary Geralda, O.P., she taught high school biology, religion, and English courses until 1965 when she left the order, married (later divorced) and returned to school. She then went on to earn a Master's degree in English and eventually her PhD in English from the University of Arkansas in 1977. For the next thirty years, Keefe taught English and Women's Studies, including at Rollins College, where she also served as Director of Women's Studies (1979-1992) and at the University of Wisconsin-Superior, 2000-2007. Her dissertation was on"The American Dream in Afro-American Drama: 1960-1970."She entered the field of Women's Studies just as it was developing and was a prolific scholar whose research focused primarily on feminist and/or lesbian theater. The author of several articles, Keefe is co-editor of"Lesbian Nuns: Breaking Silence"(1985) and editor of"Amazon All Stars: Thirteen Lesbian Plays"(1996).

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: Donor correspondence contains detailed list of contents. Additionally, all accessions have container lists that are available upon request by contacting specialcollections@smith.edu

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Rosemary Keefe Curb papers, Sophia Smith Collection, SSC-MS-00680, Smith College Special Collections, Northampton, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers include Keefe's Feminist Theater Archives, assembled as part of her research, and includes correspondence, scripts, fliers, and publications, by Keefe and others.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: To the extent that she owns copyright, the donor has assigned the copyright in her works to Smith College; however, copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. For instances which may regard materials in the collection not created by the donor, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.
